texts.ru: Кишимжан, 36 лет, замужем, мать 4 детей. В 1999 году начала бизнес по разведению скота. Кишимжан на сегодняшний день в хозяйстве имеет 2 коровы, 15 овец и 12 лошадей. На участке мерою 4,0 Га она выращивает клевер для внутрихозяйственного потребления. Совокупный среднемесячный доход составляет около 15,000 сом (KGS). Кишимжан обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку скота для откорма и реализации. Доходы от кредита позволят Кишимжан развить бизнес и построить новые сараи для скота.
texts.en: Kishimzhan is 36 years old, married and a mother of 4 children. She started her own business fattening up livestock in 1999. Today, Kishimzhan has 2 cows, 15 sheep and 12 horses on her farm. She grows clover for the farm use on 4.0 hectares of land. Her combined average monthly income amounts to about 15,000 som (KGS). Kishimzhan requested a loan in the amount of 50,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy livestock for fattening up and resale. The earnings from the loan will allow Kishimzhan to develop her business and build new barns for her livestock.

loans.use: to buy livestock for fattening up and subsequent resale

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita es una mujer de 43 años de edad, casada, tiene dos hijos de 24 y 18 años y su negocio es la venta de jugos naturales.
Ella es buena madre, independiente, responsable y trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza en la Ciudad de El Alto un sitio caracterizado por el comercio en todas las áreas de clima frio con una temperatura que oscila entre 2 a 10   grados centígrados durante todo el año. 
Margarita es de tez morena, estatura mediana, cabello negro largo, su lengua materna es el Aymara y habla español por el comercio, ella elabora jugos de frutas naturales como batidos ensalada de frutas, entre otros.  Su labor la realiza de lunes a domingo porque en el lugar el comercio es constante y no tiene descanso. Su sueño es tener un lugar amplio donde pueda ofrecer variedades de sus jugos naturales a su clientela. Ella desea ampliar su negocio realizando la compra de material de construcción Esta es la primera secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 4 años que viene realizando esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Margarita solicita un préstamo para la compra de material de construcción y de esta manera ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Margarita is a 43-year-old woman. She is married and has two children aged 18 and 24. Her business is selling natural juices.

She is a good mother, independent, responsible, and hard-working. Her business is in the city of El Alto, a place distinguished by trade everywhere. Its climate is cold, with a temperature that varies between 2 and 10 degrees centigrade throughout the whole year.

Margarita has brown skin, is of medium height, and has long black hair. Her native language is Aymara and she speaks Spanish for business. She sells natural fruit juices such as fruit salad shakes, among others. She works every day of the week because in this place there is constant business and it does not stop. Her dream is to have a large place where she can offer a variety of her natural juices to her customers. She wants to expand her business by buying construction materials. This is the first loan cycle with the institution in the 4 years she has been doing this work.

loans.use: to buy construction material and in this way expand her business

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Alma is 48 years old from Carles, Iloilo. She is married with three children, ages 12, 14 and 17. Her husband is a fisherman in their town.  Alma has supported their fishing business and helped in selling her husband's catch. She is asking for a loan to buy fishing nets, an engine, rope and lead weights. The loan will pave the way for her to have a better income. In the future, she hopes that all her children are successful while she supports their education.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets, engine, rope and lead weights

loans.name: Norhol

texts.en: Norhol is a businesswoman who was born in 1957 and lives in a village. She is married with five children. There are 12 members in her immediate family. Her husband is an entrepreneur. Supporting the large family is hard work for Norhol and her husband. She has a business buying and selling women's and children's shoes. She has a permanent place of business. Norhol is planning to expand her business. She needs financial support to buy shoes for increasing the working capital of her business.

loans.use: To buy women's and children's shoes

loans.name: Rosenie

texts.en:
Rosenie is a 43-year-old married woman with six children. She is from the town of Carles, Iloilo. She has fished for twenty years and learned how to fish from her husband.

Rosenie joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. Rosenie requests 15,000 PHP  to buy fishing nets, nails, paint, and adhesive.  Her income will be used for her children's education and to meet the  family's daily needs.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets, nails, paint, and adhesive.

loans.name: Anabil

texts.en:
Anabil works hard to support her family. Anabil is married and has a food-vending business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients like cooking oil, milk, flour, and sugar.

Anabil has been in this business for six years now. She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her business.

In the future, Anabil would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like cooking oil, milk, flour, and sugar

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
Aurelia is a 59-year-old married woman with six children, five attnd school.

Aurelia has grown vegetables for 13 years and requests 23,000 PHP through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

She has previously borrowed 12 times  from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Aurelia would like to save money to provide a good future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies,

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
As a married mother of six children, Elsa works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns income from raising livestock. Elsa is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Elsa has been sustaining her business activities through her past 18 loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a chaff cutter

loans.name: Ladina

texts.ru: Ладина, 32 года, вдова, мать 3 детей школьного возраста. У Ладины- высшее образование, работает в школе учителем кыргызского языка и литературы. В качестве дополнительного дохода для своей семьи она занимается животноводством и полеводством, стартовав 9 лет назад. Благодаря упорному труду Ладины, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 2 коровы, 2 лошади, 25 овец. На участке мерою 1,60 ГА она выращивает фасоль для реализации. Ежемесячный совокупный доход составляет 20,000 сом (KGS), однако этих средств катастрофически не хватает на достойную жизнь и содержание семьи. Поэтому, в целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Ладина обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 25,000 сом (KGS) на покупку овец для увеличения поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита она планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, что позволит улучшить благосостояние ее семьи и обеспечить достойное будущее детям Ладины.
texts.en: Ladina is 32 years old, a widow, and a mother to three elementary-school-age children. Ladina has a higher education. She works in a school as a teacher of Kyrgyz language and literature. As an additional source of income for her family, she practices livestock breeding and crop farming. She started this business 9 years ago. Thanks to Ladina's hard work, she currently has 2 cows, 2 horses and 25 sheep on her farm. On her 1.60 hectare plot of land, she grows beans for sale. Her average cumulative monthly income is 20,000 som (KGS), however this amount is catastrophically not enough for a good standard of living for her family. For the further development of her business, Ladina turned to Microfinance Bank "Bai Tushum." She is requesting a loan for 25,000 som (KGS) to buy sheep to increase the size of her herd. She plans to invest the earnings from the loan in the further acquisition of livestock, which will allow her to improve her family's living conditions and provide a good future for her family.

loans.use: to buy sheep.

loans.name: Daniel Magaji

texts.en: Daniel Magaji is a maize farmer from Ranau Danmantai village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Daniel Magaji would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Daniel Magaji can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Daniel Magaji, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for his family, and hopes to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for his family thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies to help her coffee crop.

loans.name: Elina

texts.en:
Elina is 42 years old. She is married with 2 children aged 15 and 20, both of them go to school. She is a farmer and has been farming for 10 years.

With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy more maize fertilizers for sale. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more maize fertilizers.

loans.name: Khayriniso

texts.en:
Khayriniso is a hardworking, married woman who was born in 1974. She lives in a rural area and has three children. 

She and her son sell shoes from a permanent work place. She plans to enlarge her business with additional retail facilities.  She needs financial support to buy shoes to enlarge business and accomplish her plans.

loans.use: to buy shoes.

loans.name: Yankadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Yankadi est composé des femmes mariées vivant avec leurs maris et leurs enfants dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 33 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Kalaban-coura l’un des quartiers de Bamako et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié.Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de,  condiments (oignons), légumes, gombos et aubergines. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Sitan  (femme arrêtée en 2ème position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo) a une réputation dans la vente des condiments (oignons). Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 3 sacs d’oignons en gros à Médine. La revente se fait en détails à Kalaban-coura et en ambulant à une clientèle constituée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Sitan  espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinjecté dans l’activité et subvenir aux petits besoins des enfants.
texts.en:
The group Yankadi is composed of married women living with their husbands and children in traditional families. The women average 33 years of age and three children each, all living in Kalaban-coura, a district of Bamako. And they know one another through ties of kinship, community, and friendship. The group members have small-scale businesses involving condiments (onions), vegetables, okra, and eggplants.

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their 2nd solidarity loan cycle.

Ms. Sitan (the woman standing second from the left in the photo) is known for selling condiments (onions). She intends to use her loan to purchase in bulk 3 sacks of onions in Médine. Her sales are made retail to a customer base composed mostly of women by going door to door in Kalaban-coura. She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and meeting the sundry needs of the children.

loans.use: to purchase condiments, such as onions.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase his product (fish), do repairs on the motorcycle taxi, and upholster the motorcycle taxi.

loans.name: Elias

texts.en:
Elias is 26 years old. He is married with two children. His children are between six months and three years old, and do not yet go to school. Elias is a farmer and has been farming for five years. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to buy fertilizer for the maize which he sells. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy maize fertilizer

loans.name: Meldrina

texts.en:
Meldrina works hard to support her family. She is married and has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years now.

Meldrina requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy paint, tires and gasoline for her motorcycle maintenance.

Meldrina would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy paint, tires and gasoline for her motorcycle maintenance.

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife is 46 years old, married, and has six children, two in school.

Marife is in the agricultural business in the Philippines. Marife requested a PHP 6,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Marife has been raising pigs for four years now, and has borrowed seven times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

She would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy supplies such as chicken, oil, flour, among others.

loans.name: John Didier

texts.es:
En la siembra y tala de árboles encuentran muchas personas una oportunidad para progresar y salir delante de una manera humilde y con mucho coraje, tal es el caso de John que a sus 29 años es un joven con gran talento y pasión por este oficio.
Tiene gran habilidad en este trabajo gracias a su experiencia y conocimiento empírico.
Solicita un apoyo económico para realizar la compra de una motosierra para reemplazar la que tiene en mal estado y optimizar su trabajo, la cual le permitirá continuar con su labor con el cual ha intentado obtener algunos ingresos para el sostenimiento de sus hijos y aportar con la economía de su hogar.
Una de las grandes dificultades que ha tenido que enfrentar es la falta de oportunidades para crecer y desarrollarse, pero poco a poco intentara tener una vida mejor.

Apoya a John con su trabajo y haz que su vida sea mejor con un préstamo!
texts.en:
John, 29, makes a living harvesting trees.  It's a simple living, requiring great courage, but it provides him and many people here the chance to support themselves and get ahead in the world.  

John has a lot of experience harvesting trees and has become very skilled.  He is applying for a loan that he will use to buy a new chainsaw.  The one he has is old and worn and he needs a new one to carry on his business.  The business is his main source of income and his means of supporting his children and covering the family's bills.  

One of the problems that John faces is a lack of opportunities for growing and developing his business.  Even so, he goes on working to build a better life.

Please support John's business and help him work for a better life with your loans!

loans.use: to replace his worn chainsaw.

loans.name: Daniel Dan-Asabe

texts.en:
Daniel Dan-Asabe is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Daniel Dan-Asabe joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Emma, Ibrahim and Habila.

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Daniel Dan-Asabe would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Daniel Dan-Asabe can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.

When asked, Daniel Dan-Asabe spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for children's school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her tailoring business

loans.name: Yean's Group

texts.en:
Yean’s group live in a rural village in Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Yean makes a living cultivating rice and she also does extra work as a construction worker to support her family.

In her village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Sokheng's Group

texts.en:
Sokheng’s group lives in a rural village in the Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Sokheng makes a living growing rice and has a home-based grocery  to support her family. 

Her village does not have reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. These women want  a water filter at home to help each one to safeguard their family's health, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Savorn's Group

texts.en:
Savorn’s group live in a rural village in Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Savorn makes a living cultivating rice and she also does extra work as a tailor and construction worker to support her family.

In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women and man to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Saphon's Group

texts.en:
Saphon’s group lives in a rural village in the Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Saphon makes a living growing rice and being a  tailor to support her family. 

Their village has no reliable access to safe, clean, drinking water.  They want to have a water filter at home to safeguard their family's  health, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Phen's Group

texts.en:
Phen’s group lives in a rural village in the Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Phen makes a living growing rice and being a tailor and village coordinator. 

The village does not have reliable access to safe, clean, drinking water. A home water filter will help each of these group members to safeguard their family's health, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Veasna's Group

texts.en: Veasna’s group live in a rural village in Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Veasna makes a living cultivating rice and he also does extra work as a tailor and construction worker to support his family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water.  Having a water filter at home will help each of these man and women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Shanti

texts.en:
Friends Handicraft was founded by entrepreneurs, Shanti and Nirjali, who are dedicated to helping women gain economic independence and provide for their families.  Many of the women they employ are rebuilding their lives from great hardship.  In Shanti’s words: “We are more focusing on the betterment of the women than just the profit objective. Through their work and being part of Friends Handicraft, the women are uplifting their living standards.”  Friends Handicrafts employs over 100 Nepali women and sustains the ancient technique of felting. They use this method to create unique and vibrantly colored decorations, bags, scarves, and children's gifts. Based in Kathmandu, Nepal, Friends Handicraft's mission is to combat urban poverty and foster a sense of independence in an otherwise marginalized population. Friends Handicraft provides employment, skills-training and support services including financial literacy, emergency funds and scholarships that cover school fees, uniforms and supplies for employee children. This loan will allow Friends Handicraft to create a larger work space so that they can hire more women and fulfill purchase orders more efficiently.

Friends Handicraft works closely with Global Goods Partners who is dedicated to alleviating poverty and promoting social justice. You can purchase these Nepali felt products on their website at http://globalgoodspartners.org/.

loans.use: To purchase aluminum shelter for outside work space and tables and chairs to accommodate more women artisans in a larger work space.

loans.name: Zahraa

texts.en:
Zahraa is a 21-year-old married woman who started her own tailoring business from her home four years ago. She is a hard-working Palestinian refugee who puts considerable effort into developing her living.

Zahraa is an ambitious lady who has professional skills in her domain. She is now acquiring a YOUTH loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to develop her business through buying special textiles to tailor elegant evening dresses.

Zahraa hopes open her own shop and display her special dresses, and she is keen to employ women only. She hopes to achieve this dream which will help her increase her income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to develop her business by buying special textiles to tailor elegant evening dresses.

loans.name: Sreynhar

texts.en:
Sreynhar is a 41-year-old married homemaker with three children who lives in Kampong Speu Province in Cambodia. Her husband is a 45-year-old motorcycle taxi driver. One of her three children is a factory worker, one is a gas station attendant, and one makes copper decorative objects. Together, they can make around $17 a day.

Sreynhar doesn’t have a bathroom with a toilet for her family to use so she has decided to secure a loan to buy bricks, steel and cement to build a bathroom with a toilet. This loan will provide her and her family with better living conditions and a way to keep the environment clean. She plans to buy soil to fill up the ground under her house.

loans.use: to buy bricks, steel and cement to build a bathroom with a toilet

loans.name: Lekhatola

texts.en:
Lekhatola is 20 years old and he is an accounting freshman who lives in Banteay Meanchey province of Cambodia. His father is a motorcycle taxi driver and his mother is a civil servant. 

Lekhatola is a hardworking student. Because he is short of finances to pay his university fees from the first to the fourth year, he has decided to borrow the money. This money will help him earn a Bachelor’s degree and have a chance to find a proper job for his future. As for his dream after graduation, he hopes to work in a bank.

loans.use: to pay his university fees

loans.name: Desideria

texts.en:
Desideria earns a livelihood by farming. She toils the land and grows rice. She is a  61-year-old widow woman from Talibon, Bohol with six grown children. 

She has requested a loan to buy farm supplies like fertilizers. These materials are very essential to her farming business. Her yield will improve, resulting in higher sales. Thus she will be able to manage her finances and other obligations.

Desideria dreams of improving her future status of living by handling her source of income properly.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies like fertilizers

loans.name: Ha

texts.en:
Ha, 45, is a married man who lives in a small community of Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. He is a farther of three single children. To make a living and support his family, he manages and operates a framing business on a small farmland which is located near his house. On his farmland, he grows rice and sells his agricultural product to the local dealers. On average, he can generate an earning of USD 4.00 per day.

He is now applying for a Kiva loan via HKL to buy a plot of farmland for building a house. This loan will allow him to experience owning a proper land size for building a convenient house. 

He is thankful to all lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy a plot of farmland for building a house

loans.name: Alfonso

texts.en:
Alfonso is 21 years old. His family lives at Cataggaman. He raise hogs and sell them upon achieving the desired weight. His income goes for food and other bills at home. He had an unstable income from his business, but he had a strong determination to improve his hog raising business. 

Now, he is asking for P6,000 as additional capital to improve his sales. He will buy another piglet and its feed for maintenance. 

He hopes to raise healthy hogs so he can sell them at a good price someday.

loans.use: to buy piglet and its feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Than

texts.en: Than is 45 years old, a mother of two children, and a local farmer living in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has only a single business, rice farming, to support her living, especially the daily food consumption in her household. She has been a rice farmer for several years and is able to generate about 41,700 KHR per day. This loan is Than's second loan with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She has fully repaid back her past loan, which was used to improve her living condition. She will spend her entire loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed to support her rice farm. She hopes that she can get more income to build a new house.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and rice seed to support her rice farm.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Kaiyrgul

texts.ru: Кайыргул, 35 лет, замужем, 4 детей. У Кайыргул средне-специальное образование, она занимается реализацией хлеба, покупая хлеб в пекарнях, Кайыргул продает его на рынке. Ежемесячная прибыль составляет около 30,000 сом (KGS). В этом году она решила реконструировать дом, поэтому обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 15,000 сом (KGS), целью которого является покупка цемента, кирпича, шифера и других материалов. Прибыль от продажи хлеба Кайыргул будет вкладывать в улучшение условий проживания ее большой и дружной семьи. Также она мечтает открыть собственную пекарню.
texts.en: Kaiyrgul is 35 years old, married and has 4 children. Kaiyrgul has a specialized secondary education. She is involved in selling bread - she buys bread from bakeries and resells it at a market. Her monthly profit amounts to about 30,000 som (KGS). This year, she decided to renovate her house, and this is why she requested a loan in the amount of 15,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy cement, bricks, slate and other materials. Kaiyrgul will invest the earnings from selling bread into improving the living conditions for her big and friendly family. She also dreams of opening up her own bakery.

loans.use: to buy cement, bricks, slate and other materials in order to renovate her house

loans.name: Ana Luisa

texts.es:
Ana tiene 33 años de edad es soltera vivie con sus padres en el canton San Miguel provincia de Bolivar en la comunidad Salado Chico, pertenece a la ventanilla rural San Francisco.

Ella se dedica a la agricultura hace algunos años a la siembra de maiz y tambien a la cria de animales, solicita el credito para mejorar el negocio de la cria de animales como para comprar alimento y arreglo de las chancheras, gracias al credito concedido podra mejorar su situación economica y salir adelante para cumplir con sus suños, en su tiempo libre le gusta hacer deporte.
texts.en:
Ana is 33 years old and single. She lives with her parents in the San Miguel canton, Bolivar province, in a community called Salado Chico. She is a member of the communal bank San Francisco. Ana has been working for some years now in agriculture. She grows corn and raises animals.

She is requesting a loan to improve her farming business, for instance by buying feed and repairing her pig pens. Thanks to this loan, she will be able to improve her financial situation and get ahead to fulfill her dreams. During her free time she likes to practice sports.

loans.use: to improve her pig farming business.

loans.name: Samuel's Group

texts.en:
Samuel has 6 children, is 45 years old, and lives in Simbori A village in Kuria East, Kenya. Samuel works as a subsistence farmer for a living. The community of Simbori A village does not have access to clean and safe drinking water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases like cholera and typhoid. Samuel is a friendly member of the community and has been elected promoter by his village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Samuel represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using a chlorine dispenser. Samuel and three other promoters in his community need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Samuel wants to be a promoter because he because chlorine will help treat drinking water making it safe for human use.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Samuel’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a stock of milk for making yogurt

loans.name: Veronica's Group

texts.en:
Veronica has 3 children, is 30 years old and lives in Sakuri A village Kuria East, Kenya. Veronica works as a commercial farmer for a living. Where Veronica lives, her  community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their drinking water from a local water spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Sakuri A community had a way to treat their drinking water, they could reduce the amount of water-borne diseases, keeping Sakuri A community at school and work.

This is why Veronica is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of  her community. Veronica was elected to represent her community as a volunteer promoter. She is not only representing her community on Kiva, but also volunteers her time to educate the people of her community on the importance of safe water and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at their local water point. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Veronica wants to be a promoter because she envisions a community free from water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Veronica’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Daniel's Group

texts.en:
Daniel is 34 years old, has 6 children and lives in Kenokwi village in Kuria East, Kenya. Kenokwi village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their drinking water from Kenokwi spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Daniel’s community may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Daniel works as a business owner, but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Daniel and other promoters in his community, including, Bena, John and Truphena need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Daniel will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Daniel wants to be a promoter because he believes that the dispenser will help prevent cholera and improve hygiene.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Daniel’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Rael's Group

texts.en:
Rael lives in a home with mud walls, a dirt floor and an iron roof in Nyamotambe C Taragai village in Kuria East, Kenya with her family which includes 6 children. The community of Nyamotambe C Taragai village collects their drinking water from a local well because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases often making Nyamotambe C Taragai’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. Nyamotambe C Taragai community will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe drinking water. Rael has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are 4 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Paul, Mogesi, Rael, and Esther.

Nyamotambe C Taragai community needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Rael believes that the dispenser will  help reduce diseases in her community. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Rael's community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Munsi's Group

texts.en:
Munsi has 5 children, is 30 years old and lives in Kebichohe village Kuria East, Kenya. Munsi works as a subsistence farmer for a living. Where Munsi lives, her  community does not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their drinking water from a local water spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Kebichohe community had a way to treat their drinking water, there could be fewer cases of water-borne diseases, keeping Kebichohe community at school and work.

This is why Munsi is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of his community. Munsi was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. He is not only representing her community on Kiva, but also volunteers his time to educate the people of her community on the importance of safe water and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at their local water point. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Munsi wants to be a promoter because he envisions a community free from water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Munsi’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Janet's Group

texts.en:
Janet is 46 years old, has 2 children, and lives in Ramoya A village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Ramoya A village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Ka-Clement borehole. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Janet and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Janet works as a peasant farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Janet and other promoters in her community, including Longius, Rose, and Richard need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Janet will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Janet wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine will kill bacteria in water hence making water safe for drinking.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Janet’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Charles' Group

texts.en:
Charles is 36 years old, has 3 children, and lives in Mariri A village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Mariri A village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Ka-Eunice spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Charles and his family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Charles works as a peasant farmer, but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Charles and 4 other promoters in his community, including Emily, Eunice, Marene, and Agnes need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Charles will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Charles wants to be a promoter because he believes that the chlorine will kill bacteria and germs in water making it safe to drink.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Charles’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
Rose is 34 years old, has 5 children, and lives in Ngutu village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Ngutu village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Kalawi spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Rose and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Rose works as a business owner, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Rose and other promoters in her community, Beatrice, Joel and Charlse need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Rose will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Rose wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine will help the community use safe water making them healthy and leading to a better life.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Rose’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Gabriel's Group

texts.en:
Gabriel is 52 years old, has 2 children, and lives in Achama B village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Gabriel works as a subsistence farmer for a living. His community of Achama B village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Gabriel is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by his village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Gabriel represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using a chlorine dispenser. Gabriel and 4 other promoters in his community: Peter, Eunice, Dorca, and another Eunice need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Gabriel wants to be a promoter because he believes that the chlorine will prevent water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Gabriel’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Judith's Group

texts.en:
Judith is 31 years old, has 2 children, and lives in Kalando B village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Judith works as a peasant farmer for a living. Her community of Kalando B village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Judith is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help it members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Judith represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using a chlorine dispenser. Judith and another promoter in her community called Evaline need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Judith wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine will kill germs that cause water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Judith’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Mereza's Group

texts.en:
Mereza is 35 years old, has 2 children, and lives in Konyango B village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Mereza works as a commercial farmer for a living. Her community of Konyango B village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Mereza is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help its members obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Mereza represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using a chlorine dispenser. Mereza and 3 other promoters in her community, including Dalmas, Lilian and Nicholas need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Mereza wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine will kill germs making water good for drinking.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Mereza’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Esther's Group

texts.en:
In Nyabosongo C village in Kuria East, Kenya, Esther has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program. Esther is a friendly member of the community with 4 children. Esther lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, a concrete floor and an iron roof.

Nyabosongo C village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a local spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Esther’s community needs a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Esther has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Esther volunteered to be the promoter because she wants to help the community access safe water that will help reduce water-borne diseases. There are also 2 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Catheline and Johnes.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Esther’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Grupo Bella Cruz Group

texts.es: El Grupo solidario Bella Cruz está integrado por tres mujeres laboriosas, y emprendedoras en su vida laboral; el cual es coordinado por la señora Elizabeth de 45 años de edad, acompañada, y se dedica a la venta de ropa nueva y comercialización de productos Avon desde hace dieciséis años en las calles de su localidad, esto le ha permitido el crecimiento de su negocio y aumento en las ventas. El crédito lo solicita para la compra de pacas de variedades de camisas, pantalones, talladores, toallas, pijamas, capris, perfumes, vanidades, cremas corporales, cremas para el cabello, etc. La segunda socia es la señora Ana de 52 años de edad y se dedica a la venta de prendas. Y la tercera socia es la señora Lucy de 57 años de edad quien se dedica a la comercialización de productos Avon, ropa y joyas en su localidad.
texts.en: The Bella Cruz communal bank is made up of three women who are hard-working and enterprising in their work lives. It is coordinated by Elizabeth, 45 years old, who is in a relationship. She has sold new clothing and Avon products for sixteen years on the streets of her town. This has allowed her to grow her business and increase her sales. She is asking for the loan in order to buy bundles of an assortment of shirts, pants, bras, towels, pajamas, capris, perfumes, compacts, body creams, hair creams, etc. The second member is Ana, 52  years old, who sells clothing. And the third member is Lucy, 57 years old, who sells Avon products, clothing, and jewelry in her town.

loans.use: to buy bundles of an assortment of shirts, pants, bras, towels, pajamas, capris, perfumes, compacts, body creams, hair creams, etc.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est composé uniquement de  femmes polygames. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Baco-Djicoroni  l’un des quartiers de Bamako et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de, condiments (ail et Maggi). Dans le but de se ravitailler au comptant, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1èr cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Djénèba  (femme arrêtée en 2ème position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo) a une grande réputation dans la vente des condiments (ail et cube Maggi). Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 4 sacs de l’ail et 2 cartons de Maggi en gros à Médine. La revente se fait en détails à Baco-Djicoroni   et en ambulant à une clientèle mixte. Madame  Djénèba  espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité. Elle a pour objectif d’acheter un lot à usage d’habitation dans cette relation avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The group Benkadi is composed only of polygamous women, who average 35 years of age and four children each, all living in Baco-Djicoroni, a district of Bamako. The women know one another through ties of community. The group members have small-scale businesses involving condiments (garlic and Maggi).

With the goal of replenishing their cash reserves, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their 1st solidarity loan cycle.

Ms. Djénèba (the woman standing second from the right in the photo) is known for selling condiments (garlic and Maggi cubes). She intends to use her loan to purchase wholesale 4 sacks of garlic and 2 boxes of Maggi, in Médine. Her sales are made retail to a mixed customer base by going door to door in Baco-Djicoroni. She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 40,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business. Her goal is to purchase a plot of residential land through this Soro Yiriwaso relationship.

loans.use: to purchase condiments, such as such as garlic and seasonings.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more supplies like animal feed, rice and noodles.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is a 40-year-old married woman and a mother of five children from Iloilo, Philippines. She runs a small sari-sari (variety) retail store business selling various goods and items to the people in her neighborhood.
 Vilma is asking for a loan to buy more stock to sell like eggs, canned goods, vegetables and fruits, peanuts and dried fish. With a loan, she will be able to improve her stock which will attract more buyers to her store. 
In the future, Vilma hopes of making her business a success. Moreover, she wants to save money for the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell like eggs, canned goods, vegetables and fruits, peanuts and dried fish

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn is an industrious woman who runs a sari-sari (variety) store. She sells basic household commodities like eggs, toothpaste, soap, canned goods, noodles, seasonings and soft drinks. She has been running a store for almost 10 years now. She is 32-year-old married woman with two kids, ages 10 and 3. She also farms the land, growing rice.

She is asking a loan of 15,000 PHP to buy stock for the store and farm supplies like rice seedlings and fertilizer. In this way, she could improve her harvest. Her store will be filled again with various items so buyers will shop her at store.

 In the future, Jovelyn hopes that she will be handling her livelihood at its best for the welfare of her growing children.

loans.use: to buy stock for the store and farm supplies like rice seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Felomina

texts.en:
Felomina is 60 years old and married with three children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Felomina has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines. Felomina requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy more vegetables to sell.

Felomina has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Felomina would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cynthia is 43 years old, married and has four children, two in school.  

She is in the agricultural business, raising pig in the Philippines. Cynthia requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Cynthia has been raising pigs for three years now, and has borrowed two times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Cynthia would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Vazgen

texts.en:
Vazgen is 38 years old and lives in Gandzakar, a frontier village in the Tavush region of Armenia. Vazgen is married with 2 daughters and a son, and he and his family live with his parents. 

Currently Vazgen works as part of the local police force, but he is still able to be seriously engaged in farming, agriculture, and beekeeping. With help from his father's advice and many years of farming experience, Vazgen takes care of his cattle. He has 4 cows, 2 calves, 5 sheep, 20 beehives, and a large plot of land, on which he cultivates potatoes, greens, and beans. 

Everything Vazgen raises is used equally to feed his family and to sell. His farm’s honey is especially good, and well-known in the area as it sells very quickly. 

Vazgen enjoys his farm and his life in his cute village and is happy to produce such a great assortment of farm products. The milk and dairy products, meat, honey, potatoes, and greens are all rewards for his hard and honest work on his farm and land.

Vazgen is very thankful for his first Kiva loan. Now, he hopes to soon acquire his second loan of 500,000 AMD in order to enrich his farm with the purchase of 2 more calves and fodder to feed his cattle.

loans.use: to buy 2 additional calves and fodder to feed his cattle.

loans.name: Baktygul

texts.ru: Бактыгул 58 лет, замужем. У нее высшее образование, работает в школе учителем. У Бактыгул с мужем 7 сыновей. В качестве источника дохода для своей семьи, много лет назад начала заниматься животноводством. Благодаря упорному труду Бактыгул в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется 3 коровы, 20 овец. Ежемесячный доход составляет около 15,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Бактыгул обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку жеребят. Доходы от кредита Бактыгул планирует вкладывать в развитие бизнеса посредством покупки дополнительных голов скота и для улучшения материального благосостояния семьи.
texts.en: Baktygul is 58 years old and married. She has a higher education and works in a school as a teacher. Baktygul has a husband and seven children. As a source of income for her family, she began a livestock breeding business many years ago. Thanks to Baktygul's hard work, she currently has 3 cows and 20 sheep on her farm. Her average monthly income is 15,000 som (KGS). For the further development of her business, Baktygul turned to Microfinance Bank "Bai Tushum." She is requesting a loan for 100,000 som (KGS) to buy colts. Baktygul plans to invest the earnings from the loan in the further development of her business by buying more cattle. She also intends to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase colts to increase the size of her herd.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is  a mother of three lovely children from a very remote village in Etago, the Kenyenya area of Kenya. 

She has sold milk, grown maize, and a variety of food crops for 6 years. This humble mother makes a profit selling crops, but has poor harvests because she does not have  proper farm implements. She requests 10,000 KES to buy good farm implements. This loan will help her double her production because she will buy good quality fertilizer and seeds. Modern farming practices entail using good fertilizer and good seeds to reap more  harvest and Jackline is on the right track. 

Profits from an increased harvest will be used to repay the loan and improve her living conditions.

You can help this woman improve her farming business, provide for her children, and be able to educate them. Help her out!

loans.use: to buy farm implements.

loans.name: Elvira Rosa

texts.es:
Elvira, de 38 años, inicio con un negocio de alquiler de lavadoras hace aproximadamente 4 años con el afán de buscar una actividad que le generara ingresos para poder sobrevivir.
En el momento, encuentra su motivación para trabajar incansablemente en sus tres hijos y es así como desea ofrecerles lo mejor para su vida y desarrollo.
Hoy en día sus hijos tienen 7,13 y 15 años y se han convertido en la alegría de esta mujer trabajadora.
Solicita un préstamo para la compra de lavadoras de segunda para mejorar su servicio y tener mejores ingresos.

De esta forma podrá sostener su negocio y a sus hijos brindándoles una calidad de vida mejor.

Apoya a Elvira para que pueda continuar con su actividad!
texts.en:
Elvira, 38, owns an appliance rental business.  She started the business 4 years ago because she had no income at all and desperately needed a way to live.  She hit on washing machine rentals as the way forward and continues working tirelessly to maintain it because it is her only means of supporting herself and her three children.  Her children, now 15-, 13-, and 7-years old, are, she says, the light of her life.  

Elvira is applying for a loan that she will use to buy second-hand washing machines.  The investment will allow her to provide a better service to her customers and, in turn, increase her earnings.  She wants to ensure that she can carry on her business and provide her children with a better quality of life.

Please support Elvira's efforts to maintain and grow her business!

loans.use: to buy washing machines for her appliance rental business.

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es:
Julio, de 27 años de edad, un joven muy trabajador y dedicado a su familia, está casado y tiene 1 hijo de 5 años de edad, su esposa se dedica a los oficios domésticos, actualmente su dedicación es a la agricultura y la ganadería, posee 4 vacas lecheras que le dan el sustento para su familia. 

Julio, se ha dedicado a la agricultura desde que tenia 12 años de edad, además de cultivar maíz, cultiva frijol, maicillo y caña de azúcar, también trabaja ordeñando sus 4 vacas que le ayudan con algunos ingresos para su familia.

Todo lo que sabe, es gracias a su padre que con gran esfuerzo le ha enseñado a cultivar la tierra y al manejo del ganado bovino.

El dinero lo necesita para comprar 3 terneras, para engordarlas y luego venderlas, con las ganancias que espera obtener por la comercialización de este ganado, espera darle mejores condiciones de vida y alimenticias a su hijo y esposa.

Julio desea además, aumentar su producción de caña de azúcar ya que le es muy rentable.
texts.en:
Julio, 27 years old, is a young man who is very hardworking and dedicated to his family. He is married and has one 5-year-old son. His wife makes a living as a housekeeper. Currently, Julio works full-time in agriculture and ranching. He has 4 dairy cows that provide sustenance for his family. 

Julio has made a living in agriculture since he was 12 years old. In addition to growing corn, he grows beans, sorghum and sugar cane. He milks his 4 cows to help with some income for his family. 

Everything he knows is thanks to his father, who with great effort taught him to cultivate the land and to manage livestock. 

He needs the money to buy 3 calves, to fatten them and later to sell them. With the profit he expects to make from the sale of this livestock, he hopes to give better quality of life and nutrition to his son and wife. 

Julio also hopes to increase his production of sugar cane to make it more profitable.

loans.use: to buy 3 calves, to fatten them and later to sell them.

loans.name: Nazia

texts.en:
Nazia 31, lives in Lahore and helps to support her family. Her younger brother  has a driving license and wishes to start his profession.

 Nazia has applied for a loan to help her brother buy an auto rickshaw so that he can earn money and become self sufficient. Her dream is that her brother could start saving money and become responsible. 

She thanks BRAC Pakistan for this opportunity.

loans.use: to buy a new rickshaw for her brother.

loans.name: Yahaya

texts.en:
Yahaya is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Yahaya would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cover his immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yahaya can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Like other Babban Gona members, Yahaya is looking  to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing for his family, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Amina joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Gadafi and Biliya.  

Before she became a Babban Gona member, Amina would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cover her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Amina can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked, Amina  spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to ensure her children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To pay her children's school fees and buy their uniforms, thus eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Neou's Group

texts.en: Neou’s group live in a rural village in Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Neou makes a living cultivating rice to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Yern''s Group

texts.en:
Yern’s group lives in a rural village in the Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Yern makes a living growing rice to support her family. 

Her village does not have reliable access to safe, clean, drinking water. The groups want a water filter at home to help each member safeguard their family's health, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha  comenta que su objetivo principal es obtener su título universitario de contadora pública y poder trabajar en su profesión y además  emprender un negocio independiente. 
Martha pide este préstamo para poder pagar sus cuotas de la carrera, y poder seguir con sus estudios como lo viene haciendo. Agradece por la oportunidad que recibe de poder estudiar.
texts.en:
Martha says that her main goal is to obtain her university degree in public accounting and to be able to work in her profession. She also wants to set up her own company. 

Martha is asking for this loan in order to be able to pay her course fees, and to continue her studies as she has been doing. She is grateful for the opportunity she has received to be able to study.

loans.use: to pay her university fees.

loans.name: Mariana

texts.es:
Mariana es la mayor de los hermanos, vive en la ciudad de Pilar, estudia la carrera de Derecho. A la vez que estudia, también trabaja, comenta que su sueño es poder recibirse de Abogada para ir escalando mejorando en su trabajo.
Ella es una persona muy trabajadora y luchadora, que quiere ser alguien en la vida.
Pide este préstamo para poder cubrir sus cuotas de la carrera.
texts.en:
Mariana is the oldest child in her family. She lives in the town of Pilar and is a law student and also has a job. Her dream is to qualify as a lawyer so she can start on the ladder to a good job.

Mariana is a hardworking person, committed to making something of herself in life. She is seeking a loan so she can pay her school fees.

loans.use: pay school fees

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les six femmes du groupe Danaya sont mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogamiques. Elles ont en moyenne 41ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes Baco-Djicoroni ACI l’un des quartiers de  Bamako; Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu à Baco-Djicoroni ACI. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce d’habits, de l’arachide, de balaies, d’oignons  et des ustensiles. Dans le but de se ravitailler au comptant, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1èr cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Téneba  (femme  arrêtée à l’extrême  droite sur la photo) a une grande réputation dans la vente des habits (pagnes wax) de meilleures qualités ; Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 16 pièces de pagnes wax à  Bamako en gros; La revente se fait à Baco-Djicoroni ACI à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Téneba  espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les soins de santé des enfants.
texts.en:
The six women of the group Danaya are married for the most part in monogamous households. They average 41 years of age and five children each, all living in Baco-Djicoroni ACI, a district of Bamako. The women know one another through ties of community and their revenue-generating businesses in Baco-Djicoroni ACI. The group members have small-scale businesses involving fabrics, peanuts, brooms, onions, and utensils.

With the goal of replenishing their cash reserves, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their 1st solidarity loan cycle.

Ms. Téneba (the woman standing at the far right in the photo) is known for selling Wax 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa) of the best qualities. She intends to use her loan to purchase wholesale 16 lengths of Wax ‘pagne’ cloth in Bamako. Her sales are made retail to a customer base composed mostly of women in Baco-Djicoroni ACI. With this loan, she hopes to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and meeting the healthcare needs of the children.

loans.use: to purchase cloth

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more supplies of beverages, soft drinks, canned goods, noodles, biscuits, candies, and seasonings to resell.

loans.name: Sinignesigui Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sinignèsigui est composé des femmes mariées vivant avec leurs maris et leurs enfants dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 38 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Baco-Djicoroni ACI l’un des quartiers de Bamako et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de, condiments, poissons fumés et balaies. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Maïmouna (femme arrêtée à l’extrême droite sur la photo) a une réputation dans la vente des condiments. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  5 corbeilles de tomates à Médine. La revente se fait en détails à Baco-Djicoroni ACI et en ambulant à une clientèle constituée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Maïmouna espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinjecté dans l’activité et subvenir aux petits besoins des enfants.
texts.en:
The group Sinignèsigui is composed of married women living with their husbands and children in traditional families. The women average 38 years of age and five children each, all living in Baco-Djicoroni ACI, a district of Bamako. The women know one another through ties of kinship, community, and friendship. The group members have small-scale businesses involving condiments, smoked fish, and brooms.

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their 1st solidarity loan cycle.

Ms. Maïmouna (the woman standing at the far right in the photo) is known for selling condiments. She intends to use her loan to purchase 5 baskets of tomatoes in Médine. Her sales are made retail to a customer base composed mostly of women by going door to door in Baco-Djicoroni ACI. With this loan, she hopes to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and meeting the sundry needs of the children.

loans.use: to purchase condiments, such as tomatoes

loans.name: Dario

texts.en: Dario is a farmer residing in the town of Talibon, Bohol, Philippines. He is a 57-year-old married man with six grown children. He engages in vegetable farming. He grows vegetables such as eggplant and bottle gourd, and he grows rice for additional income. Dario is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies. These are essential to achieve high yields. With the fertilizers and farm supplies, he can sell more vegetables and rice to his customers. Dario dreams of managing his current business successfully, to improve his livelihood, and to have a stable source of income.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Luis Yohalmo

texts.es: Luis de 37 años de edad habita junto a su compañera de vida, sus 4 hijos de 12, 8, 4 y 1 año de edad, su suegra y su cuñado. Él es un hombre emprendedor que se esfuerza cada día para poder llevar el sustento diario a su hogar apoyado en su trabajo como promotor de golosinas a nivel departamental. Luis siempre ha tenido el sueño de contar con un lugar propio donde vivir, por lo que desde algún tiempo está construyendo su vivienda propia, pero por falta de liquidez económica no ha logrado concluir la obra, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: arena, ladrillo, cemento, hierro, lámina y polines para terminar de construir su vivienda, lo antes posible y poder ofrecerle un lugar propio a su familia.
texts.en:
Luis, 37 years old, lives with his life's companion and their four children, ages 12, 8, 4, and 1, and his mother-in-law and brother-in-law. He is an enterprising man who works every day to bring in the necessary daily sustenance for his home as a producer of sweets at the department level.

Luis has always had the dream of having his own home to live in and for some time, he has been constructing his own home, but for lack of economic liquidity, he hasn't managed to complete work. For that reason, he is requesting a loan through FUSAI to invest in sand, blocks, cement, iron, laminated sheets, and rafters to terminate construction of his house as soon as possible and to be able to offer his family an appropriate place to live.

loans.use: invest in sand, blocks, cement, iron, laminated sheets, and rafters to finish construction of his home.

loans.name: Lidia Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Lidia comerciante de venta de ropa y zapatos usados, así como también perfumes en su casa de habitación a quien le gustaría en un futuro tener su establecimiento en uno de los mercados de la capital, su crédito anterior lo invirtió en realizar divisiones en su hogar lo cual ha venido a mejorar las condiciones de vida, ahora Lidia solicita el crédito para comprar materiales de construcción para continuar mejorando la parte posterior de su vivienda en la cual necesita levantar un muro perimetral para garantizar la seguridad a su familia y la de sus pocos bienes que le han costado mucho esfuerzo adquirirlos, doña Lidia va mejorando su casita gradualmente ya que el costo de los materiales están muy caros por lo que va por etapas, esperando culminar del todo la obra muy pronto.
texts.en:
Doña Lidia is a businesswoman selling used clothing and shoes, in addition to perfumes in her home. In the future she would like to have her store in one of the markets of the capital. She invested her past loan to put dividing walls in her home, and that has improved her quality of life. 

Now Lidia is requesting a loan to buy construction materials to continue improving the posterior part of her home. She needs to erect a perimeter wall to guarantee the security of her family and her few belongings, which have required great effort to acquire. 

Doña Lidia is improving her little house gradually since the materials are very expensive. For this reason she is going in stages, hoping to finish the whole job very soon.

loans.use: to ensure the construction of the perimeter wall of her home, to guarantee the security of her family and her few belongings.

loans.name: Blonie

texts.en:
Blonie is married and works hard to support her family. She has a rice "buy and sell" business in the Philippines. 

She has requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell.

Blonie has been in this business for 30 years now. She would like to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en:
Cherry is 30 years old and married with three children, one of whom is in school. She is in the agricultural business, raising poultry in the Philippines, and has requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy feeds and vitamins for her poultry.

Cherry has been raising poultry for five years now and has borrowed from NWTF 12 times in the past to sustain her business. In the future, Cherry would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her poultry.

loans.name: Arsena

texts.en:
