As a married parent of 14 children, Arsena works hard to support her family.

She has a buy and sell vegetable business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store, raising pigs, and buying and selling charcoal.  

Arsena is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to buy additional vegetables to sell in her food stall for her buy and sell vegetables business.

She successfully repaid her previous loan, and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Arsena has been sustaining her business activities through her past 21 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional vegetables to sell in her food stall

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy is 47 years old and married with four children, one of whom is in school. Juvy works very hard to provide for them.

Juvy runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell.

Juvy has been in this business for eight years, and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, noodles and other groceries. 

In the future Juvy would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en:
As a married mother of 11 children, Meriam works hard to support her family. She has a rice retailing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store.  

Meriam is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF in order to buy more stock of rice to sell.

Meriam has been sustaining her business activities through her past 12 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy more stock of rice to sell.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
“When women come together, they are powerful,” says Monica, a 22-year-old farmer who has two children and lives in the village of Sisiya in the Kapsowar area of Kenya. As a girl, she watched women in her village mobilize to replace traditional thatched roofs with waterproof corrugated iron. The memory of this collective effort led her to join Ogilgei self-help group. 

For the past year, Monica has been actively involved in mixed farming. Because she is from rural Kenya, gender roles still adhere and women do the heavy work of fetching and carrying water and wood, in addition to household chores, childcare and tending crops. Many are left to run farms alone while their husbands migrate in search of paid employment. 

This has not been a setback because Monica has been making great profits in farming. Kapsowar is one of the places with conditions that favor horticulture farming: good climate, soils, transport system, and market. Monica has always wanted to diversify and start horticultural farming, but the biggest challenge she has been facing is lack of funds. She is therefore requesting a loan to start horticultural farming. Through the Ogilgei self-help group, whose members co-guarantee each other to secure a loan, Monica joined Juhudi Kilimo, a micro-finance organization that supports young and enterprising farmers. 

With your loan Monica intends to buy good quality vegetable seeds, flowers and potatoes. Proximity to an airstrip will allow her to transport the produce faster to an international market, hence enabling her to make more money. This loan will improve Monica's living conditions and secure the future of her children.

loans.use: To start horticultural farming

loans.name: Hour's Group

texts.en:
Hour, 54, is a villager in Kampong Cham province and a mother of five children. She secures the basic needs in her family via cassava and rice growing. 

This is Hour's third cycle with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) and she has fully repaid her past loan successfully. She is leading a group of three members to get a new loan. She will spend her loan to buy seed and pay labor fees. She hopes that she can earn more income to improve her family's living conditions and make them better than before.

loans.use: To buy seed and pay labor fees.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Rakip

texts.en:
"Rakip is a good man"; this is how other villagers described him. They spoke very fondly of him, according to the loan officer who disbursed him for the second time. 

With the loan that you lent to him, he built the stable that he intended to and he expressed his deepest gratitude to the Branch Assistant who took the loan impact interview from him. 

Now, with the loan that he is requesting from you again, he wants to buy a dairy cow and he hopes very much that he will get your financial help this time around as well.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Napono

texts.en:
Napono is 48 years old, widowed and a mother of two children. She sells goats in Narok town and has been in this business for 15 years. 

She plans to use this loan to buy goats to sell. She will use the anticipated profits to buy cattle. 

This is her first loan term from VisionFund Kenya and her future hopes are to expand her farming business and be successful.

loans.use: To buy goats to sell.

loans.name: Oktam

texts.ru: Октам, 49 лет, замужем, 3 детей. У Октам - среднее образование, в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи, она занимается животноводством, стартовав с покупки скота на 5,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорному труду Октам, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 1 корова, 1 теленок, 21 овцы. Ежемесячный доход Октам составляет 15,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, она обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 150,000 сом (KGS) на покупку скота и корма для животных. Доходы от кредита Октам планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины и хочет накопить средства на свадьбу и образование ее детей.
texts.en: Oktam is 49 years old, married, and has three children. Oktam has a secondary education. As the main source of income for her family, she practices livestock breeding. She started this business with a purchase of cattle in the amount for 5,000 som (KGS). Thanks to Oktam's hard work, she currently has 1 cow, 1 calf, and 21 sheep on her farm. Oktam's average monthly income is 15,000 som (KGS). For the further development of her business, she turned to Microfinance Bank "Bai Tushum." She is requesting a loan for 150,000 som (KGS) to buy cattle and livestock feed. Oktam plans to invest the earnings from the loan in the further acquisition of livestock. She also intends to save money for her children's weddings and education.

loans.use: to purchase cattle and livestock feed.

loans.name: Meyeyu

texts.en:
Meyeyu runs a hotel in Narok town in Kenya. For the past 15 years, she has worked hard in her business, giving her the means to support her family. She is 43 years old, married, and, together with her spouse, they have been blessed with 5 children. 

Meyeyu has requested a loan from VisionFund Kenya in order to buy more inventory of flour, sugar, cooking oil, and cereals which she will use in her hotel. This will enable her to serve more customers, earn more income, and, accordingly, expand her business. 

This is Meyeyu's first loan term, and her future hopes are to expand her business and be successful.

loans.use: to purchase a supply of food to sell.

loans.name: Rafik

texts.en:
Rafik lives with his retired mother in Kadjaran city in the Syunik region. He is 44 years old and still not married. His mother has a great dream to see her son finally happy with a wife and children. 

Rafik has a vocational education and for several years he worked at the Kajaran combine. Now he works at a private company as a locksmith. 

He says that after so many years he suddenly met a person who he wants to become his wife and with whom he wants to establish a family full of love, respect and many children. 

He already made a proposal of marriage to that lady who is also very happy to become his wife. Rafik says his mother is very impatient and happy for the coming marriage party of her son.

Rafik is asking for a loan of 300,000 Armenian drams in order to organize a nice, cute and cheerful wedding party, which will be during the New Year’s holidays, so in the new year the couple will start together with great wishes to be happy many-many years.

loans.use: to organize a nice, cute and cheerful wedding party.

loans.name: Brian

texts.en:
Brian is 20 years old and married. Together with his spouse, Judy, he has been blessed with one child. He does poultry farming in Narok town. He also sells shoes, and it has been profitable.

He plans to use this loan to buy more stock of poultry for rearing. He will use the anticipated profits to buy more poultry.

This is his first loan term from VisionFund Kenya, and his future hopes are to have a successful business and succeed in life.

loans.use: to buy more stock of poultry for rearing.

loans.name: Dilorombuvi

texts.ru: Дилоромбуви женщина 40 лет,замужем ,мать-героиня  шестерых детей.После замужества она начала заниматься животноводством.На участке земли,который достался ей от отца,она начала разводить скот и выращивала картошку,которую продавала на рынке.На деньги ,полученные от продажи,она покупала скот и сейчас у нее в стаде пятнадцать баранов.Ей нравится работать на поле,ухаживать за скотом,кормить,выращивать и продавать урожай.Во всех ее делах ей помогают ее дочери.Дилоромбуви понимает,что в настоящее время образования необходимо,поэтому она работает не покладая рук , чтобы обеспечить своих детей и дать высшее образование.Дилоромбуви обратился в МДО Арванд за получением кредита для покупки корма для скота ,так как у нее нет полной суммы денег.Она надеется на положительный ответ со стороны МДО Арванд и благодарит за поддержку и доверие.
texts.en: Dilorombuvi is a 40-year-old married woman and a mother of six children. She became involved in animal husbandry after getting married. She started to raise livestock and grow potatoes for sale on a land inherited from her father. She bought livestock with the money from livestock sales and now has a herd of fifteen sheep. She likes to work on the field, take care of, feed and raise livestock and sell her harvest. Her daughters help her with all of her activities. Dilorombuvi understands that education is necessary in the present day and this is why she works hard to provide for her children and give them an opportunity to get a college education. Dilorombuvi requested a loan from MDO Arvand to buy livestock feed because she does not have enough of her own money. She hopes for a positive result from MDO Arvand and is grateful for the support and trust.

loans.use: to buy livestock feed

loans.name: I's Group

texts.en: I’s group live in a rural village in Prey Veng province in Cambodia. I makes a living cultivating rice and planting corn to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each group member to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Yum's Group

texts.en:
Yum’s group lives in a rural village in the Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Yum makes a living growing rice, sewing, construction, and sell grocery from home.

The village has no reliable access to safe, clean, drinking water. A home water filter  will help each member to safeguard their family's  health, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en: Rowena is from Cauayan City, Isabela, Philippines. She is married and blessed with three children. They own a sari-sari store (local convenience shop), and her husband works as a driver. Their combined income is sometimes insufficient for their expenses. That’s why she is asking for a 200,000 PHP loan from KIVA lenders to pay the tuition fee of her son, Charles John. Charles is working toward a BS in Marine Transportation. He wants to finish college, to help his family out of poverty, and to improve their lives.

loans.use: to pay for her son's tuition fee.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: pay his school fees

loans.name: Angela

texts.es:
Angela viene de una familia humilde, sus padres son artesanos en cuero, mediante el apoyo de sus padres procura  terminar su estudios universitarios, para que pueda tener un futuro mejor.
Angela esta estudiando la carrera de derecho, y comenta que su aspiración es terminar  su carrera y comenzar a trabajar en alguna rama de su carrera.
Pide este prestamo para poder pagar las cuotas de su carrera, y de esa forma poder seguir con sus estudios como lo viene haciendo.
texts.en:
Angela comes from a humble family. Her parents are leather artisans. With the support of her parents, she is trying to finish her university studies so she can have a better future.

Angela is studying law, and she notes that her dream is to finish her degree and start working in some branch of her field. She is asking for this loan in order to be able to pay for the fees for her degree, and in that way be able to continue with her studies as she has been doing.

loans.use: to pay university fees

loans.name: Sharifamoh

texts.ru: Шарифамох жительница района Дангара, занимающаяся в сфере продаж. Она в течение двух лет торгует на рынке детской и женской одеждой. Шарифамох 27 лет. Она не замужем и живет с родителями, младшим братом и двумя младшими сестрами. Шарифамох ведет свой торговый бизнес при поддержке отца. Она хороший продавец и знает толк в своем бизнесе. Чтобы увеличить товарооборот и расширить бизнес, Шарифамох просит кредит. Она хочет приобрести ассортимент сезонной детской одежды для привлечения большего количества клиентов и увеличения объема продаж. Шарифамох нуждается в вашей поддержке.
texts.en: Sharifamoh is a resident of the Dangara District. She works in the field of retail sales. For two years, she has been selling children's and women's clothing at the market. Sharifamoh is 27 years old. She is unmarried and lives with her parents, younger brother and two younger sisters. Sharifamoh runs her retail business with the assistance of her father. She is a good saleswoman and knows the intricacies of her business. In order to increase her sales turnover and expand her business, Sharifamoh is requesting a loan. She wants to buy an assortment of seasonal children's clothes to attract more customers and increase her sales volume. Sharifamoh relies on your support.

loans.use: to buy an assortment of children's clothes for retail sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for poultry

loans.name: Claudia Trinidad

texts.es: Claudia es una mujer de 29 años de edad y habita en vivienda propia junto a su compañero de vida y sus 2 hijos de 8 y 2 años de edad. Ella es una mujer trabajadora que se gana la vida con su pequeño huerto de frutas, ya que vende por mayoreo las frutas de temporada, además vende hojas de huerta la cual utilizan para elaborar los deliciosos tamales de gallina. Claudia desea adquirir un crédito con FUSAI para invertir en: ventanas, cemento, arena y grava para cambiar las ventanas y repellar las paredes de su vivienda lo antes posible y así dar un poco más de seguridad a su vivienda. Agradece el primer crédito que recibió dado que de esta forma logró repellar parte de las paredes de su vivienda, pero no le alcanzo para hacer todas las mejoras previstas, por lo que nuevamente solicita crédito para continuar con la mejora de la vivienda.
texts.en:
Claudia, 29, and her husband have a house where they live with their 2 children, 8- and 2-years old, respectively.  She grows fruit in her small garden and sells what she harvests to wholesalers.  She also grows and sells the garden vegetables that people here use to make their delicious chicken tamales.

Claudia is applying for a FUSAI loan that she will use to buy materials--windows, cement, sand, gravel, etc.--for replacing her worn-out windows and replastering the outside walls of her house.  She wants to carry out the work as soon as possible to make the house a little safer.  

Claudia used a past loan to replaster some of the walls of her house but the loan didn't stretch far enough to finish the project.  This new loan will allow her to continue the work.

loans.use: to buy building materials for making improvements to her house.

loans.name: Baara Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des ménages polygamiques, les quatre  membres du groupe Baara ont en moyenne 44 ans et 6 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Kanadjiguila dans la commune du Mandé / cercle de Kati et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenu à Kanadjiguila. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce du savon, des fruits, des friperies et du charbon de bois. Dans l’intention d’accroitre leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2èmecycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Sira  (femme arrêtée à l’extrême  gauche  sur la photo) est une grande vendeuse des savons de plusieurs sortes. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  25 cartons de savons en gros à Bamako. La revente se fait en détails à Kanadjiguila en ambulant à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Sira  compte avoir avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 95 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et satisfaire les petits besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
Married for the most part in polygamous households, the four members of the group Baara average 44 years of age and six children each, all living in Kanadjiguila, in Commune de Mandé/ Cercle de Kati. And the women know one another through ties of community and their revenue-generating businesses in Kanadjiguila. The group members have small-scale businesses involving soap, fruit, secondhand clothing, and charcoal.

With the goal of growing their business capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their 2nd solidarity loan cycle.

Ms. Sira (the woman standing at the far left in the photo) is known for selling soaps of several types. She intends to use her loan to purchase 25 boxes of soaps wholesale in Bamako. Her sales are made retail to a customer base composed mostly of women by going door to door in Kanadjiguila. With this loan, she plans on making an average monthly profit of 95,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and meeting the sundry needs at home.

loans.use: to purchase soaps

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en: Wilson is a shrewd and hard-working man living  the outskirts of Lyantonde town. He owns a garage as well as a spare parts shop in the same area. He needs the money to buy motorcycle spare parts and provide good services to his clients who usually want spare parts that he sometimes lacks. He is grateful that the financial boost will expand his business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for repairing motocycles

loans.name: Munini

texts.en:
Munini is 51 years old. She is married and blessed with 6 children, two of whom are in school. 

Munini is a farmer. She has been in this business for the last 7 years, earning a monthly income of KES 9,800. Munini has requested her first loan with VisionFund Kenya. She is requesting KES 20,000, which she will use to buy fertilizers and seedlings for planting.

With the anticipated profits, Munini will be able to educate her children. Her hope and dream for the future is to become self-reliant.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seedlings

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Sreypao's Group

texts.en:
Sreypao’s group lives in a rural village in the Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Sreypao makes a living growing rice and working construction to support her family. 

The village has no reliable access to safe, clean, drinking water.  A home water filter will help each member to safeguard their family's  health,  save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for the family.

loans.name: Hun's Group

texts.en:
Hun’s group lives in a rural village in Prey Veng province in Cambodia.

Hun makes a living cultivating rice, and she also does extra work as tailor to support her family.

In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Yoweri

texts.en:
Yoweri is a young man, aged 25, who does cattle rearing and fattening. He has requested a loan of UGX 800,000 to help him buy a cow for slaughter during the celebration of the Christmas festival. This will help him maximise profits since everyone will be buying meat.

Yoweri is still single and looking forward to forming his own family and a house. The major problem is that he pays school fees for his siblings, yet his income is not enough to sustain him and his siblings. He hopes with continuous financial boosts and support, his income base will grow and so will his business. He is hard-working and resilient.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is a 48-year-old married woman with six children who works hard to provide for her family. 

She has run a gasoline business for 5 years and requests 20,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase gasoline to sell.

Monica has borrowed and repaid 2 previous loans from NWTF. She  earns additional money raising pigs.

Monica aspires to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional gasoline to sell.

loans.name: Hat's Group

texts.en:
Hat’s group lives in a rural village in the Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Hat makes a living growing  rice, corn, and watermelons. She does extra work as a tailor to support her family. 

The village has no reliable access to safe, clean, drinking water. A home water filter will help group members to safeguard the family's health, save money on medical expenses, and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: to buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for the family.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es: FRANCISCA lives in La Paz and she is a widow but she strongly believes in God and she thinks that is the reason she is still alive and working well Francisca has a grocery store In the beginning she used to sell fruits and vegetables but in time and with a lot of effort she increased the items or products to sell Francisca has 5 sons but all of them are adults already and they have their own expenses. She lives alone and she is asking for a loan to sell bread, to buy more soft drinks, to sell eggs and food cans Francisca has a lot of experience in this area because she has the store in her own house since 30 years She thanks the help from Kiva Francisca is a very determined and independent person she hopes you can trust her
texts.en:
FRANCISCA lives in La Paz and is a widow. She believes strongly in God and thinks that is the reason she is still alive and working well. Francisca has a grocery store. In the beginning she used to sell fruits and vegetables but in time and with a lot of effort she increased the number of products she has to sell. 

Francisca has 5 children but all of them are adults already and they have their own expenses. She lives alone. She is asking for a loan to sell bread, to buy more soft drinks, to sell eggs and cans of food. Francisca has a lot of experience in this area because she has had the store in her own house for 30 years. She is grateful for Kiva’s help.

Francisca is a very determined and independent person and hopes you will trust her.

loans.use: to sell bread, to buy more soft drinks, to sell eggs and food cans in her grocery store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay university fees

loans.name: Romie

texts.en: Romie, a farmer from San Mariano, Isabela, is married to an overseas Filipino worker and blessed with three children. Even though the two of them are earning income, it is sometimes insufficient to meet all the needs of their children. That is why, to send his son to college, Romie wants to borrow a PHP 200,000 education loan from Kiva lenders. That amount will pay for his son's tuition fees. His son Richard is studying for a bachelor of science degree in accountancy because he dreams of becoming a successful certified public accountant.

loans.use: to pay for his son's tuition.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 56 and has two adult-age children. She engages in buying and reselling dry goods in the public market to help her husband in gaining income. She has been in this business for more than five years.

Agnes wants to continue and improve her business but she has insufficient capital. For this reason, she wants to avail herself of an additional PHP 30,000 to buy more pants, short pants, baby wear, t-shirts, blouses, skirts, pajamas, jerseys, etc. to resell.

Having this financial assistance, Agnes believes that someday she will further improve her business and make it more profitable in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional pants, short pants, baby wear, t-shirts, blouses, skirts and pajamas to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy flour, cooking fat and sugar for use in her hotel.

loans.name: Diego

texts.es:
Diego estudia la carrera de administración de empresas, y está cursando el segundo  año, quiere ser un profesional útil a la sociedad por medio de sus conocimientos.
El esta poniendo todo de si para poder destacarse en lo que hace y poder ayudar a las demás personas.
Pide este préstamo para poder cubrir los gastos de sus útiles, y de esa forma poder seguir con sus estudios y continuar luchando.
texts.en:
Diego is studying Business Administration and is in his second year. He wishes to become a professional who can use his knowledge to play a useful role in society.

He is putting his whole being into doing well so that he can help other people. Diego is seeking a loan to cover the cost of university supplies so that he can continue working hard in his courses.

loans.use: pay for university supplies

loans.name: Milagrita

texts.en:
Milagrita engages in a hog-raising business. She grows and sells hogs. Aside from that, she also runs a sari-sari (variety) store, selling various merchandise like noodles, canned goods, sugar, soap and seasonings. She has been engaged in this kind of business for a year now. She is married and a mother of three children aged 22, 19 and 10 years old.

Milagrita is asking for a loan of 20,000 PHP to buy additional pigs and pig feed. This will help Milagrita raise and sell more pigs. In the coming months, she will continue operate her hog-raising business. She can now start to pay her loan and other household expenses.

In the future, Milagrita dreams to expand both her businesses to make them productive and profitable.

loans.use: to buy additional pigs and pig feed.

loans.name: Balimaya Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de quatre femmes, les membres du groupe Balimaya sont mariés majoritairement dans des ménages polygamiques. Elles ont une moyenne  d’âge de 44 ans et 7 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Kanadjiguila dans la commune  du  Mandé/ cercle de Kati. Elles se sont connues à travers des liaisons de parenté, de voisinage et  de leurs activités génératrices de revenu. Les membres du groupe font la vente d’habits (pagnes wax et léger), de  l’arachide, du bois de charbon et des condiments. Dans  le souci de constituer leurs stocks de vente, les membres du groupe ont décidé de faire recours à  Soro Yiriwaso  et  sont  à leur  3ème cycle de  prêt  solidaire.
Madame Kancoumba (femme arrêtée à l’extrême gauche sur la photo) est une grande vendeuse des habits (pagnes wax et légers) de bonnes qualités. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 20 pièces de pagnes wax et 18 pièces de léger. Elles s’approvisionnent en habits à Bamako. La revente se fait à Kanadjiguila au comptant ou à crédit en ambulant et parfois par commande à une clientèle composée majoritairement  de femmes. Madame Kancoumba compte  réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 100 000 FCFA par mois, qui sera utilisé, pour assurer les soins de santé des enfants. Elle a pour objectif d’augmenter le volume de son activité dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
Composed of four women, the members of the group Balimaya are married for the most part in polygamous households. The women average 44 years of age and seven children each, all living in Kanadjiguila, in Commune de Mandé/ Cercle de Kati. And the women know one another through ties of kinship, community, and their revenue-generating businesses. The group members have small-scale businesses involving Wax 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa) and light-weight fabrics, peanuts, charcoal, and condiments.

Concerned about building their inventory, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their 3rd solidarity loan cycle.

Ms. Kancoumba (the woman standing at the far left in the photo) is a major vendor of cloth (Wax and light ‘pagne’) of good qualities. She intends to use her loan to purchase 20 lengths of Wax ‘pagne’ cloth and 18 lengths of light ones. Accepting cash or credit, she makes her sales retail to a customer base composed mostly of women by going door to door, and sometimes by special order, in Kanadjiguila. With this loan, she plans on making an average monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used for ensuring the children’s healthcare. Her goal is to increase her business volume through this Soro Yiriwaso partnership.

loans.use: to purchase cloth

loans.name: Maria Fe

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Maria Fe works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines,and earns additional income from farming rice and pig fattening.  Maria Fe is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like chips, eggs, milk, and sugar for her general store business.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested this loan to further build her businesses.

Maria Fe has been sustaining her business activities through her past 24 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like chips, eggs, milk, and sugar.

loans.name: Luis Miguel

texts.es:
En Santo Domingo de los Colorados vive Luis, un joven de 21 años, muy emprendedor y trabajador. Desde que estuvo estudiando comenzó a ahorrar para ponerse su negocio, comenzó de a poco vendiendo confitería, luego ya sus ventas se superaron, ahora todos los días en horario de salida de los estudiantes él vende confitería fuera de los establecimientos escolares, el resto del día atiende en un pequeño local donde además vende víveres.
Tiene el apoyo de su familia, son muy unidos y sencillos. Con el crédito otorgado por la institución comenta que lo va a invertir en la tienda de abarrotes ya que quiere surtir su negocio e incrementar sus ventas ya que en este mes las ventas son súper buenas.
Agradece a Fundación Alternativa y al proyecto Kiva por permitir que jóvenes microempresarios se superen en sus negocios.
texts.en:
Luis lives in Santo Domingo de los Colorados. He is a 21-year-old young man, and is very driven and hardworking. He started saving to start his own business when he was in school. He started at the bottom, selling pastries. Gradually his sales began to increase, and now he sells his pastries outside different schools at the end of the school day, when students leave the building to go home. During the rest of the day he runs a small store where he also sells groceries.

He has the support of a very close and humble family. He says he will invest this loan in his grocery store because he wants his business to be well stocked and his sales to increase, since sales were great this month. He wants to thank Fundación Alternativa and the Kiva project for allowing young micro entrepreneurs like himself to move their businesses forward.

loans.use: to stock up on merchandise.

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia is a 50-year-old married woman with three children, two attend school. Letecia works very hard to provide for them.

She has run a general store for 10 years and requests 22,000 PHP through NWTF to buy shampoo and groceries to sell .

In the future Letecia, would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy shampoo and groceries to sell.

loans.name: Hayrapet

texts.en:
Hayrapet lives with his youngest son and lovely wife in Kapan city in the Syunik region of Armenia. His eldest son and daughter are already both married and living separately with their families. 

Despite being without higher education, Hayrapet has worked in many different spheres. Nevertheless, he has always been able to provide his big family with a decent standard of living. 

Today, Hayrapet continues to ignore his age and work as actively as he did as a young man. Not only a poultry farmer and famous bee keeper, he is also a taxi driver and earns a profit from his plot of land with the nice apple orchard he established. 

Hayrapet currently has 20 beehives and recently decided to increase the number in order to sell more honey each spring season. He is requesting this loan in order to buy several beehives and special two-storied boxes which keep more bees. He also plans to buy fodder for his chickens.

loans.use: to buy several beehives, special boxes for bees, and fodder for his chickens.

loans.name: Marilen

texts.en:
Marilen is single and has a clothing sales business in the Philippines.

Marilen requested a PHP 15,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) in order to buy more stocks of clothing to offer for sale.

Marilen has been in this business for 15 years now and also earns additional income from performing manicures.

In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of clothing to offer for sale.

loans.name: Hayarpi

texts.en:
This young lady with a nice smile lives in Kapan, a city of the Syunik region. She is 23 years old and she lives with her mother and brother. Hayarpi is a student at the Yerevan State Pedagogical Institute at the distance learning department, in the faculty of Foreign Languages and the department of English Language and Literature. Simultaneously with her education, she has always worked; she has worked at one of the local TV channels as a journalist and at the municipality as a secretary. Now, she finally works at the school of her specialty; she is a teacher of English Language. She also gives private courses of English Language to a group of pupils who have difficulties in their learning at the school. This lady is a very clever and intellectual person who is a beloved teacher among all her pupils. Hayarpi’s mother works at the market as a saleswoman and her brother both studies and works as a cook. Hayarpi’s mother mentions that she is greatly proud of her children who honestly work, receive higher education and care for their future. 
Hayarpi asks for a loan of 250,000 Armenian drams in order to buy a computer; she wants it to make her courses more interesting, as she could find a lot of new methodological tricks for attracting her pupils.

loans.use: to buy a computer.

loans.name: Tukamulane Group

texts.en:
Patuma thanks Kiva's lenders for the previous loan that they granted her. She used her portion of the loan to buy more bales of secondhand clothing, and this helped her meet her customers' demands, thereby increasing her profits.

Patuma is requesting another loan. She wishes to open a shop in her area, but now she will be selling new clothing. She intends to start this new business so she can further increase her profits and her sources of income.

Patuma plans to use her profits to pay her children's medical bills and school fees.

loans.use: to buy inventory of new clothing to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her clothing business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy supplies for her tailoring business

loans.name: Markus Nari

texts.en: Markus Nari is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Markus Nari would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Markus Nari can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Markus Nari is looking  to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for his family, thereby eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Sandeep

texts.en:
Sandeep is a 22-year-old banking and insurance student in Bhubaneswar city. He belongs to a poor family in a small village of Cuttack district of Odisha. His parents are farmers with three children. His siblings are in school.

While he is lacking in finances to pay his tuition fees for one year, he would like to secure a loan. This loan will help him to successfully complete a diploma course in banking and insurance. After completion, he is going to find a job in a bank.

He is very happy with this loan and thankful to Kiva for this great support.

loans.use: to pay for his banking and insurance course fee.

loans.name: Hauwa'u Sa'adu

texts.en: Hauwa'u Sa'adu is a maize farmer. She joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Maryam, Kadija, and Hauwa.  Before she became a Babban Gona member, Hauwa'u Sa'adu would sell her maize for low prices soon after the harvest, to provide for her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Hauwa'u Sa'adu can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. When asked, Hauwa'u Sa'adu spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to ensure that her children have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for children's school fees and uniforms

loans.name: Elizabeth Samaila

texts.en: Elizabeth Samaila is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Elizabeth Samaila would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Elizabeth Samaila can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Elizabeth Samaila, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for her family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for her family, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en: Mathew is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Mathew joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Joshua, Yuwana and Lami. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Mathew would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Mathew can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Mathew spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for his children's school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Benko Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de cinq femmes, les membres du groupe Benko sont majoritairement  mariés dans des ménages monogamiques. Elles ont une moyenne  d’âge 45 ans et 6 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Kanadjiguila commune du Mandé / cercle de Kati. Elles se sont connues à travers des liaisons de parenté, de voisinage et  de leurs activités génératrices de revenu. Les membres du groupe font la vente de, pâte d’arachide, macaronis et du bois de chauffe. Dans  le souci de constituer leurs stocks de vente, les membres du groupe ont décidé de faire recours à  Soro Yiriwaso  et  sont  à leur  3ème cycle de  prêt  solidaire.
Madame Nakou (femme arrêtée  à l’extrême gauche sur la photo) a une bonne réputation dans la vente de pâte d’arachide. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  5 sacs de grains d’arachides. Elles s’approvisionnent en grains d’arachides à Médine. Pour faire la pâte d’arachide, on trie les meilleurs grains, les grille, les épluches et les Broie au moulin. La pâte ainsi faite est prête à la vente en détails à une  clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Nakou compte  réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50 000 FCFA par mois, qui sera utilisé, pour assurer la scolarisation et les soins de santé des enfants.
texts.en:
Composed of five women, the members of the group Benko are married for the most part in monogamous households. The women average 45 years of age and six children each, all living in Kanadjiguila, in Commune de Mandé/ Cercle de Kati. And the women know one another through ties of kinship, community, and their revenue-generating businesses. The group members sell peanut butter, macaroni, and firewood.

Concerned about building their inventory, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their 3rd solidarity loan cycle.

Ms. Nakou (the woman standing at the far left in the photo) has a good reputation for selling peanut butter. She intends to use her loan to purchase 5 sacks of peanuts. She gets her supplies of it in Médine. To make peanut butter, the best peanuts are sorted, roasted, pealed, and then ground in a mill. The peanut butter is thus ready for retail sale to a customer base composed mostly of women. With this loan, she plans on making an average monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA that will be used for ensuring the children’s schooling and healthcare needs are met.

loans.use: to purchase peanuts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy corn, beans, pork cracklings, fresh cheese, chairs, tables, etc.

loans.name: Fokaben Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Fokaben est composé uniquement des femmes mariées vivant avec leurs maris et leurs enfants dans des familles nucléaires. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Kanadjiguila dans la commune du Mandé / cercle de Kati et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce d’ustensiles plastiques, du lait en poudre, des habits et des fruits. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Mariam (femme arrêtée à l’extrême gauche sur la photo) a une réputation dans la vente des ustensiles de toutes sortes. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 60 pièces en ustensiles en gros à Bamako. La revente se fait en détails à Kanadjiguila et en ambulant à une clientèle constituée majoritairement de femmes. Madame Mariam espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 90 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinjecté dans l’activité et subvenir aux petits besoins des enfants.
texts.en:
The group Fokaben is composed only of married women living with their husbands and children in nuclear families. The women average 30 years of age and four children each, all living in Kanadjiguila, in Commune de Mandé/ Cercle de Kati. And the women know one another through ties of kinship, community, and their revenue-generating businesses. The group members have small-scale businesses involving plastic utensils, powdered milk, clothing, and fruit.

With the goal of increasing their business capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their 2nd solidarity loan cycle.

Ms. Mariam (the woman standing at the far left in the photo) is known for selling utensils of all sorts. She intends to use her loan to purchase 60 pieces of utensils wholesale in Bamako. He sales are made retail to a customer base composed most of women by going door to door in Kanadjiguila. With this loan, she hopes to make an average monthly profit of 90,000 francs CFA that will be used for reinvesting in her business and meeting the sundry needs of the children.

loans.use: to purchase utensils

loans.name: Miguel Angel

texts.es: Miguel de 63 años de edad es un hombre emprendedor que se gana la vida con su negocio de elaboración y venta de muebles de madera actividad que realiza desde hace 30 años. Él habita en vivienda propia junto a su compañera de vida y su nieto de 14 años de edad. Miguel en su afán por mejorar sus ingresos desea comprar madera y otros materiales necesarios para elaborar los muebles que tanto le solicitan pero que actualmente vende por encargo, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: madera, clavos, tornillos, pega, barniz, etc. Para poder elaborar muebles y tener ya elaborados cuando le soliciten y así tener una mayor cantidad de clientes y obtener un mejor margen de ganancias.
texts.en:
Miguel is 63 years old. He is a driven man who earns a living manufacturing and selling furniture. He has been in business for thirty years. He lives in his own home with his life partner and their grandson, who is fourteen. 

In order to improve his income, Miguel wants to buy wood and other materials that he needs to manufacture his furniture, which is in high demand. Currently he manufactures his items as orders come in, but he would like to manufacture furniture so that it is ready for sale as soon as customers make a request. This would allow him to have more customers and obtain a higher profit margin. These are the reasons why he is requesting a loan from FUSAI so that he can invest in purchasing wood, nails, screws, glue, varnish, etc.

loans.use: to invest in wood, nails, screws, glue, varnish, etc.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry does farming in the town of Machakos and has been in this business for 10 years now.  He is 60 years old and married, and he and his spouse have been blessed with 3 children. 

He will use this loan to buy more farm inputs such as fertilizer and seeds for planting on his farm. He will use the anticipated profits to buy more farm inputs. 

This is his first loan term from VisionFund Kenya. In the future, he hopes to improve his farming and be successful.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs for use on his farm.

loans.name: Mrangirangi Group

texts.en:
Junior is in her late 30's, single, and has 2 children who are still in school. She has been a food vendor for 2 years now. She works each day from 6:00 am to 10:00 pm and is able to make a small profit each month.

This will be Junior's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She successfully repaid her previous loan which she used to buy serving dishes and restock supplies for her mamalishe, a food vending business. She used her profits to pay her children's school fees and cover her household expenses. 

Junior will use this current loan to buy serving dishes, pay rent, and increase supplies for her mamalishe. She dreams of one day building her own house.

Junior will share this loan with Mrangirangi, her loan group which has three members who will hold each other accountable for repaying the loan.

loans.use: to buy serving dishes, pay rent, and increase supplies for her mamalishe.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria, 29 years of age and married, has been running a beauty salon business in town for the last four years, and it has been profitable. Her spouse also provides additional income to support the family, and together they have been blessed with three children.

She has requested a loan from VisionFund Kenya. She will use the loan to buy more stock of beauty products for use in her salon business. She will use the anticipated profits to expand her salon.

This is her first loan term from VisionFund Kenya. Her future hopes are to be successful in her business.

loans.use: to buy more stock of beauty products.

loans.name: Geghecik

texts.en:
Geghecik lives in the village of Geghamavan in the Gegharkunik region of Armenia. She lives with her husband and son. Geghecik’s husband is a taxi driver, and her son is currently unemployed and looking for work. Geghecik has no higher education. For several years she worked at the kindergarten as a cook. Now she is engaged in farming and agriculture.  

Geghecik does her best to help her husband to sustain their family's needs. With the help of her son she takes care of her livestock: 2 cows, 2 bulls, a calf, 2 pigs, and 15 sheep. Despite great damage to her farm and very great financial expenses, she did not give up her idea of improving her business. Her cattle barn and her house burned down last year, and her family had to start over from scratch. Fortunately, these troubles are behind her, thanks to many kind people, Geghecik’s friends, and her family’s relatives. 

Geghecik is requesting this loan in order to buy a lot of animal fodder so she can keep her cattle warm and fed this winter.

loans.use: to buy a lot of fodder for her cattle

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 58 years old, married and, together with her spouse, has been blessed with four children. She has a retail shop and does farming. She has been in this business for six years. 

She plans to use this loan to buy goods such as rice, flour and cooking oil for selling. She will also buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer for use on her farm. She will use the anticipated profits to buy seeds for planting on her farm. 

This is her second loan term from VisionFund Kenya and she repaid her previous loan successfully. Her future hopes are to expand her farming business, be successful and live well with her family.

loans.use: to buy goods for selling and farm inputs for use in her farm.

loans.name: Liana

texts.en:
Liana is 37 years old and she lives with her big family in the Achanan village in the Syunik region. Liana is married and she has three pretty daughters. Liana has a higher education in pedagogy, but she never worked since she got married very early. But, as she says, her specialty turned out to be very useful for bringing up her three children. Lian’s husband now works at the gas station and, in his own car, he also manages to give taxi services. As she says, she  very much loves her husband who always tries to earn more money and provide their beautiful daughter with better living conditions. Liana now is engaged in poultry raising and, from her farm, sells a lot of eggs and poultry as well. She also cultivates vegetables (beans, cucumber, tomato, greens and onions) and wheat on her plot of land, the half of which she sells right from her house. 
Now, this loan Liana asks for in order to buy vegetables seedlings and diesel fuel for spring sowing activities, since now seedlings and diesel are cheaper than they will be in the spring.

loans.use: to buy vegetables seedlings and diesel fuel for spring sowing activities.

loans.name: Tusharkanta

texts.en:
Tusharkanta requests this loan to pay for his banking and insurance course fees. He is taking a banking and insurance diploma course as a part-time course at a reputable institute in the capital city, Bhubaneswar, in Odisha.

Tusharkanta has a graduation degree, but is required to have a diploma degree in banking and insurance to get a good job in the banking sector, as he wants to join a bank in the future.

His parents are farmers and live in a small village, and he live in a boys’ hostel in Bhubaneswar for this course. He would like to thank Kiva for this support.

loans.use: to pay for his banking and insurance course fees.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy supplies for his farming business.

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
As a married mother of 2 children, Sharon works hard to support her family. She has a general store in the Philippines and also earns additional income from her buy-and-sell charcoal business.  

Sharon is requesting a 30,000 PHP loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation in order to purchase items to sell in her general store like shampoo, soap, canned goods, fabric conditioner, etc.

Sharon has been sustaining her business activities with help from her past 3 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, fabric conditioner, etc.

loans.name: Isah

texts.en: Isah is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Isah would have to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to provide for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Isah can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Isah is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for his family, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en: Naseem is a young housewife in Lahore. Her husband has a boutique business where he takes boutique orders for a variety of formal and casual dresses, completes them and then distributes them to different boutiques at a reasonable profit margin. He has a managed to get a good customer base. He is hardworking and, as he is still establishing himself in the market, he is not self sufficient. Belonging to a not a very well-off family, financial constraints are always there. To buy materials like fabric, threads of different colors and varieties, beads, and needles, he needs money. Naseem has therefore requested a loan to help her husband. She is hopeful that this investment will pay off. They both are pleased and thankful to Brac Pakistan and Kiva.

loans.use: to buy material for her husband's boutique business.

loans.name: Rawda Al- Omeri Group

texts.en:
This group is called Rawda Al- Omeri. It consists of four women from the city of Sana'a, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 180,000 YER from AMB.

Rawda is the leader of the group. She is 33 years old and has five children. Her husband works as a bus driver with a daily wage that is not enough to provide the family with their needs. Rawda decided to help him through working as a tailor. She works inside her house with some small equipment and sewing materials. Rawda wants to expand her business but she doesn't have enough money.

The house where she lives with her family is small. It is built with just bricks and it is threatened to fall down at any time. The hoarfrost easily penetrates inside the house. Rawda wants to make the house warm and strong. For this reason, she applied for a loan of 50,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase cement and sand to renovate the house from the inside to make it warm.

Rawda hopes to renovate her entire house.

loans.use: to purchase cement and sand to renovate her house from the inside

loans.name: Micah Dogo

texts.en: Micah Dogo is a maize farmer from Shawai village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Micah Dogo would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Micah Dogo can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Micah Dogo, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for his family, and hopes to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for his family, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a maize farmer from Auchan village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Hassan would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Hassan can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Hassan, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to provide food and clothing for his family, and hopes to ensure other members of his community are lifted out of poverty.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for his family, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ibrahim would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ibrahim can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Ibrahim is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for his family, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Maria De La Paz

texts.es: María es una mujer de 62 años de edad que se gana la vida con su negocio de venta de medicamentos, además presta sus servicios domésticos obteniendo ingresos extra que le permiten sostener la economía de su hogar, también cuenta con el apoyo de sus hijos ya mayores de edad que le aportan a la economía de su hogar. Ella habita en vivienda propia al lado de su hija de y su hijo ya mayores de edad desde hace 20 años. María desea comprar más medicamentos para vender ya que como se observa en la fotografía son pocos con los que cuenta, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: medicamentos para tener mayor cantidad de productos para ofrecer a su clientela.
texts.en: María is a 62-year-old woman who makes a living with her business selling medications. She also offers her domestic services, earning extra income that allows her to sustain her household's finances. She also has the support of her children, already grown, who contribute to the household finances. For 20 years she has lived in her own house next to her daughter and her son, already grown. María wants to buy more medications to sell since, as you can see in the photograph, she has very few. For that reason she is asking FUSAI for a loan to buy medications in order to have a larger quantity of products to offer her customers.

loans.use: to buy medications in order to have a larger quantity of products to offer her customers

loans.name: Manuel De Jesus

texts.es: Manuel de 21 años de edad habita en vivienda propia al lado de su compañera de vida, por lo que se siente feliz de tener un lugar humilde pero propio en donde vivir. Él es un joven emprendedor que se gana la vida en un taller de estructuras metálicas, en el cual ha aprendido a elaborar productos como: portones, puertas, balcones y verjas, todo a base de hierro. Manuel anteriormente solicitó un crédito a la institución con el cual repelló y pintó las paredes de su vivienda, por lo que solicita un nuevo crédito que le permita instalar energía eléctrica en su vivienda, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: alambre eléctrico, caja térmica, toma corriente, postes, etc., para instalar energía eléctrica en su vivienda.
texts.en:
Manuel is 21 years old and lives in his own home with his life partner. He is happy to have a place to live that is his own, even though it is humble. He is an enterprising young man who earns a living working at a metal shop, where he has learned how to manufacture products like gates, doors, balconies, fences, and other metal structures, all wrought in iron. 

Manuel used a previous loan to plaster and paint the walls of his house, and now he is requesting a new loan from FUSAI that will allow him to install electricity in his home. He will invest it in electrical wire, a circuit box, outlets, posts, etc. to connect his house to the electrical grid.

loans.use: to buy electrical wire, a circuit box, outlets, posts, etc. to install electricity in his home.

loans.name: Lanny Marina

texts.es: Lanny es una mujer de 26 años de edad que se levanta desde muy temprano todos los fines de semana para atender su negocio de venta de verduras, el cual los días de semana es supervisado por su madre, mientras ella se gana la vida con su trabajo  en una empresa cercana. Ella habita en vivienda propia junto a su compañero de vida y sus dos hijos una niña de 8 años y un varón de 6 años de edad. Lanny desea invertir en su negocio de verduras, ya que en época navideña las ventas son mejores por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: tomates, papas, pepinos, güisquiles, plátanos, chile verde, etc.
texts.en: Lanny is a 26-year-old woman who gets up very early in the morning every weekend to look after her business selling vegetables, which her mother supervises during the week while she earns a living with her job at a nearby business. She lives in her own house with her life partner and her two children, an 8-year-old girl and a 6-year-old boy. Lanny wants to invest in her vegetable business, since sales are better during the Christmas season, so she is asking FUSAI for a loan to buy tomatoes, potatoes, cucumbers, chayote, bananas, green chile, etc.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, potatoes, cucumbers, chayote, bananas, green chiles, etc.

loans.name: Mohiniso

texts.en: Mohiniso is a hardworking woman. She was born in 1973. She lives in a village. She is married. She has two children. She has had a business for about two years. She is renting a place for her business. She buys and sells women's clothes. She had a business before of selling food. Now, she is renting a house to live in. She wants to enlarge her business and maximize her profit. She needs financial support for buying a new collection of clothes for retail. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy new collection of clothes for retail.

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en: Nasiba is a cheerful woman. She was born in 1984. She lives in a rural area. She is married and has one child. She works in the agricultural field and has five years of experience. She plants and sells an agricultural product. She has a ground where she plants crops. Recently, she has an empty ground where she is planning to plant cotton and potatoes. She needs financial support to buy seeds and amend the ground.

loans.use: to buy seeds and amend the ground.

loans.name: Toshpulod

texts.en: Toshpulod is a handsome man. He was born in a rural area. He is single. He is a student. He is studying in instruction by correspondence. He works in the national military. He is a very responsive and hardworking guy. He earns money. His goal is in good graduation of his university. Toshpulod wants to be useful for the community. He is in need of financial support for paying his university tuition.

loans.use: To pay for his tuition

loans.name: Tuygunoy

texts.en:
Tuygunoy is a hardworking woman. She was born in 1971. She lives in a village. She is married and has four children. Toygunoy has a big family; she is a responsive and goal-oriented woman. Her husband works as a cabinetmaker abroad. He opened a furniture plant in his home country. Unfortunately, his activity failed.

She decided to make an agriculture business. She is working on land from her childhood. She has been sowing potatoes and wheat. She hopes to gain income from her activity and wants to widen her business.

Tuygunoy needs financial support to buy seeds and mineral fertilizers for the new sowing season.

loans.use: to buy seeds and mineral fertilizers for the new sowing season.

loans.name: Jardin Group

texts.es:
Ana es una mujer de 43 años de edad, casada, tiene 3 hijos de 16, 8 y 12 años, y su negocio es la venta de comida.
Ella es buena madre, generosa, comprensiva, buena oyente, solidaria, responsable y trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza en su puesto de venta que se encuentra en la zona del Quinto Anillo de la ciudad de Santa Cruz De clima cálido y húmedo, con una temperatura ambiente que varía durante el día entre 20-35 grados centígrados.
Ana es de tez morena, cabello negro habla español por el comercio (sentada en el centro con blusa blanco y celeste). Su vida la comparte con su esposo que trabaja como empleado y sus hijos; todos estudian en la escuela. Viven en una casa alquilada que cuenta con agua potable, electricidad, alcantarillado y gas. Sus deseos de superación la hicieron formar una banca de personas con negocios como; tapizado de vehículos, venta de jugos batidos, venta de cubiertas de celulares,  venta de jugo, venta de perfumes, venta de refrescos y venta de ropa, para solicitar un préstamo y ampliar sus negocios. Su negocio Su negocio es la venta de comidas típicas del lugar, como; Locro de gallina (sopa; pollo dorado, arroz, papas picadas), Majadito (carne deshidratada, arroz, plátano frito y huevo), zonzos en pacumuto (yuca molida con queso a la parrilla), todo acompañado de refrescos tradicionales como; Chicha (preparada en base a maíz) y Somó(similar a la Chicha pero incluye el hervido del maíz). Esta es la primera secuencia de préstamos con la institución en un año que lleva con esta actividad. Su sueño es tener un restaurante, y desea ampliar su negocio realizando la compra de mesas y sillas para atender a mayor cantidad de clientes. Labor que realiza todos los días de la semana y recorre las diferentes ferias de la ciudad para vender su comida. “aprendí a cocinar desde muy niña porque le ayudaba a mi mamá, luego me independicé y actualmente tengo clientes fieles que me buscan diariamente…” comenta. Su sueño es tener una casa propia. Ella desea ampliar su negocio mediante la compra de mesas y sillas para atender a sus clientes de forma adecuada. Esta es la primera secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 10 años que viene realizando esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Ana solicita un préstamo para la compra de mesas y sillas para atender a sus clientes de manera adecuada.
texts.en:
Ana is a 43 year old woman, she is married with three children aged 16, 12 and 8 years old and her business is in selling food. Ana is a good mother, she is generous, understanding, a good listener, solidary, responsible and hard-working.  

Ana's business operates in the Quinto Anillo zone in the city of Santa Cruz. The weather is warm and humid, the daily temperature is between 25 - 35 degrees.  

Ana is brown-skinned, has black hair, and is Spanish-speaking for business (in the photo Ana is seated in the center with a white and blue blouse). Ana shares her life with her husband - who works as an employee, and her children - who are all in school. Ana and her family live in a rented home that has potable water, electricity, a sewerage system and gas. 

Ana's desire to go forward  saw her form a group with other people with businesses such as: vehicle upholstery, selling smoothies, selling cell-phone covers, selling juices, selling perfume, selling drinks and selling clothes, in order to request a loan and expand their businesses. In Ana's case, her business is in typical food such as: Locro de gallina (soup, browned chicken, rice, chopped potatoes), Majadito (dried meat, rice, fried banana and egg),  zonzos en pacumuto (ground cassava, with grilled cheese). As well, this food is accompanied by traditional drinks such as: chicha (prepared with a corn base) and Somó (similar to chicha but also includes boiled corn). 

This is the first sequence of loans with the institution in the year that Ana has been carrying out this business. Her dream is to have a restaurant, and she wishes to expand her business by buying tables and chairs to be able to serve a larger quantity of clients. Ana works every day of the week, going around to the different city markets selling her food. Ana says: "I learnt to cook when I was a young girl because I helped my Mother, later I became independent and nowadays I have loyal clients that seek me out everyday".   

Ana's dream is to have her own home. She wishes to expand her business by buying tables and chairs to be able to serve her clients in a convenient way.

loans.use: to buy tables and chairs

loans.name: Shehnaz

texts.en:
Shehnaz, 47 and a mother of three children, is a dedicated housewife. Her husband is a barber by profession and runs a barbershop in a crowded market in Lahore. He is hardworking and has years of experience. He has many loyal customers. He wants to give his children a better life. As they are financially not very well-off, meeting all the family expenses is always a challenge. 
As the tools and equipment used by him are subject to depreciation, he wants to buy new tools and equipment for his shop so that he can continue his work without any disturbance.
Shehnaz wants to help her husband and has requested a loan from Brac Pakistan, Kiva's field partner. They are pleased and hopeful for a better future.

loans.use: to help her husband buy tools and equipment for his barber shop.

loans.name: Mileinis Paola

texts.es: Mileinis, tiene 25 años de edad y está dedicada a la venta mediante guías especializadas de productos por catálogos, a través de los cuales promueve los artículos de su oferta, fue motivada por su madre para que iniciara su propio negocio en enero del año 2014, y a la fecha ha logrado consolidar a un grupo de amigos y familiares como sus principales clientes, a quienes les brinda facilidad de pago. Ella les ofrece productos para el cuidado de la piel  y el cabello, perfumes, joyería y demás artículos del catálogo. Esta mujer es habitante de un barrio en el municipio de Soledad junto con su hija de dos años, a quien desea brindar un excelente porvenir, Mileinis labora muy comprometida de lunes a domingo, en el horario de 8 a.m. a 6 p.m. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual invertirá en unos encargos de productos de cuidado de la piel  y el cabello, perfumes, joyería y ropa para aprovechar la temporada decembrina. Ella desea mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia, así mismo mejorar las ventas para obtener mas ganancias.
texts.en:
Mileinis is 25 years old and makes a living selling products from specialized catalogues, through which she promotes the items she sells. She was motivated by her mother to start her own business in January of 2014, and to date she has managed to bring together a group of friends and relatives as her principal clients, for whom she makes payment easy. She offers them products for hair and skincare, perfumes, jewelry, and other items from the catalogue. 

This woman lives in a neighborhood in the city of Soledad with her 2-year-old daughter, to whom she wants to provide an excellent future. Mileinis works with great commitment from Monday to Sunday, from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. 

Currently she is applying for a Kiva loan, the first funding from the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation, with which she will invest in some orders of hair and skincare products, perfumes, jewelry, and clothing to take advantage of the December season. She wants to improve her quality of life and that of her family, she also wants to improve her sales in order to make more profit.

loans.use: to invest in some orders of skin and haircare products, perfumes, jewelry, and clothing

loans.name: Nita

texts.en:
Nita is 41 years old and married with eight children.

She earns a living by pig fattening in the Philippines. Nita is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Nita has been pig fattening for 2 years and also earns additional income from farming sugarcane.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en:
With 4 children to raise, water to fetch, and food to cook, Clementine has little time to make money to provide financial support for her family. Although her responsibilities are critical to her family’s well-being, running the household is considered a mere duty in Kenya, a job with little appreciation. 

Hello, lenders! The above picture presents Clementine, a mother who has been practicing agriculture for the last 10 years. She also keeps a dairy cow. Because of her immense knowledge of farming, she commands a lot of respect among other farmers and she is viewed as a mentor in her village. She lives together with her children in the Eldoret area of Kenya, which is known for maize plantations and producing milk for export. Her primary income sources are eggs, milk, and some personal business she engages in to supplement her meager income. Generating an income by selling the harvest is the part of farming she enjoys most. 

Availability of labor is a major challenge for Clementine. Before joining Juhudi, Clementine could not access loans from banks because they considered her a high-risk client. She mobilized marginalized farmers and created the Riverside self-help group. Through the group, she joined Juhudi Kilimo and learned about loan management and agribusiness. She also got to learn about Kiva. Clementine is seeking a loan in order to construct a cow shed and to purchase farm implements. With your loan, Clementine will introduce zero grazing (an environmentally sound method of cattle care) and purchase more effective modern tools that will make her farm activities much easier. This will boost her income and enable her to pay school fees for her children.

You can help this woman to improve her farming in order to provide for and educate her four children. Help her out!

loans.use: To construct a cow shed and to purchase farm implements

loans.name: Yakubu

texts.en: Yakubu is a maize farmer. He joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Isah, Adamu, and Jery. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Yakubu had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest in order to provide for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yakubu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. When asked, Yakubu spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to pay for children's school fees and uniforms

loans.name: Samaila

texts.en: Samaila is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Samaila joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Ayuba, Benjamin and Manassah. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Samaila would have to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to provide for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Samaila can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Samaila  spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for his children's school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Indo

texts.en:
Indo is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Indo joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Barnabas, Habila, and Yusuf.

Before she became a Babban Gona member, Indo would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Indo can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.

When asked, Indo spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, and hopes to eventually make more money for herself and her family.

loans.use: to pay for her children's school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell her corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Mathew Nahabi

texts.en:
Mathew Nahabi is a Babban Gona maize farmer. 

In the past, because he needed to pay his pressing expenses, Mathew Nahabi would typically have sold his maize soon after harvest, but when prices were lowest. However, now that he is a member of Babban Gona, with their support and this loan, he can store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more. 

Like other Babban Gona members, Mathew Nahabi is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family. He also hopes to one day become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for his family thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Mika

texts.en: Mika is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Mika joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Jibo, Inusa and Asabe. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Mika would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Mika can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Mika spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to pay for his children's school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Yusuf Alhaji

texts.en: Yusuf Alhaji is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. He joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Amina, Halima, and Ibrahim. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Yusuf Alhaji would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing.
